status_message:
A message from Truthout's editor-in-chief, Maya Schenwar:

We've always worked really hard at Truthout, but lately things have been in particular overdrive, as you can imagine. Every day, we're putting our all into publishing the truth about this brutal administration. We run on an extremely tight budget considering the amount we accomplish: As our publisher Joe Macaré put it, we run a daily national publication on a local budget. Unlike almost any outlet you can think of, we don't take ads or corporate sponsors, we don't partner with the Democratic Party, and we don't sell our email list. This means we get to be truly independent and publish amazing, rad stuff (which is why I love this organization so darn much)! It also means staying alive can be hard, and we need your help right now. Giving to Truthout is a way that you can take action. I hope that those of you who are able to donate will do so.
link_name: Donate

status_message:
It's happening even more rapidly than anyone anticipated: Uncorrupted, uncensored journalists are going from a rare species to an almost extinct one. Donald Trump is keenly aware of the power of media to influence people and he's working to lock it down. Unfortunately, the mainstream media is playing along -- attending off-the-record meetings and keeping their headlines euphemistic -- whether out of fear or a desire to keep access to power.

At Truthout, we don't seek access to power and we won't be intimidated into editorial compliance. We work tirelessly to prevent a future where only far-right media has a voice. Can you help us raise the $8,000 more we still need in order to keep doing that?

There's only one day left to raise these funds: If you've been wondering how you can make a difference, now is the time to take action. Will you support Truthout today?

To join our efforts: http://www.truth-out.org/donate-now/#top

status_message:
You will not find a news outlet that has been more forthright in our criticism of Democratic policies while simultaneously being unequivocal about the dangers of Donald Trump. Truthout is committed to being rigorously independent from political parties, but uncompromisingly committed to justice, equality and truth. We will call white supremacists out by name, we will call xenophobia, Islamophobia and anti-Semitism what they are, and we will detail how the new president's policies will harm women, working people and the world.

This work is not going to get any easier. A free press is going to be incredibly necessary in the years to come, but attacks on press freedom are likely only to increase. Truthout doesn't have a big war chest -- all we have is you, our readers. Will you help us prepare for the challenges ahead?

status_message:
Too many of us didn't see this coming. In the wake of Donald Trump's appalling election victory, some soul-searching is inevitable and appropriate. Many of us will find ourselves asking: Did we do enough?

But the real question is: What do we do now? For us at Truthout, as grim as this morning feels, the answer is that we will re-commit to doing the hard work that needs to be done. We must all protect the people who are most likely to be targeted by the Trump administration, we must listen to them and we must amplify their voices.

We will redouble our efforts to bring you the truth about white supremacy, about voter suppression, about attacks on the rights of workers, women, immigrants, Muslims, Black and Brown and Indigenous people and all people of color, trans and other LGBT people -- and of course so many people who fall into many of those categories. We will cover the threat of yet more war, surveillance and militarism and we will cover the efforts of the brave people who we believe will come together in resistance.

Truthout has always been committed to holding elected officials of all stripes accountable, while being unafraid to say that we are not unbiased and objective when it comes to injustice, to inequality, to corruption, bigotry and hate. Nothing will deter us from our mission. We hope you will continue to join us in fighting for a better future, no matter the odds.

In solidarity,

Maya Schenwar, Joe Macaré and the Truthout Team

status_message: The uneven development of capitalism, coupled with its drive toward colonialism, has consistently produced the extreme conditions and extreme inequalities that sustain successive waves of migration. Thus, a solution can only be found by confronting capitalism itself.

status_message: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has ruled that the state's controversial Act 13 is unconstitutional, calling it a special law that benefits the shale gas industry. link_name: Pro-Fracking Law Ruled Unconstitutional by Pennsylvania Supreme Court

status_message: Zahara Heckscher now relies upon a medication that costs $54,000 a year. Her insurance company has denied her physician's request for the drug to slow down the cancer. The new anthology "Who Do You Serve, Who Do You Protect?" addresses urgent questions like: Do police in the United States keep anyone safe and secure other than the very wealthy? How do history and global context explain recent police killings of young Black people in the US? Come celebrate and learn more about Truthout's first-ever print collection at Bluestockings!

Contributors to the book including Aaron Miguel Cantú, Ejeris Dixon, Victoria Law and Nicholas Powers will discuss with the book's co-editor Joe Macaré the national and local issues raised by "Who Do You Serve, Who Do You Protect?" The book will be available for purchase (and signing!).

We believe that getting reliable information about the world fulfills a fundamental human need. So we've made it a point to build our budget around voluntary donations: You'll never see a paywall at Truthout.

We rely on our readers' willingness to occasionally pitch in whatever small amount you can. If you believe in unfettered access to the news, can you contribute today? http://www.truth-out.org/donate-now/

status_message: Tiny Okinawa is home to 75 percent of US bases in Japan. In the 1950s, under the perceived threat from the former USSR, the US built 39 bases in Okinawa, displacing many landowners. Plans to give lump-sum payments for land drew massive protest rallies, and eventually a rental plan was established. Much of Okinawa-owned land was conceded at the end of a bayonet or bulldozer. To this day, not one piece of land has been returned to any landowner.

status_message:
Come celebrate  and learn more about Truthout's first-ever print anthology, "Who Do You Serve, Who Do You Protect?" 

Published by Haymarket Books, this collection addresses urgent questions like: Do police in the United States keep anyone safe and secure other than the very wealthy? How do history and global context explain recent police killings of young Black people in the US?

At Volumes Bookcafe in Wicker Park, contributors to the book Andrea Ritchie, Kelly Hayes, Sarah Macaraeg and Monica Trinidad will discuss the national and local issues raised by the reports and essays in "Who Do You Serve, Who Do You Protect?" The book will be available for purchase (and signing!) - as will coffee, beer, wine and other drinks, and pastries.

status_message:
Truthout's first anthology, "Who Do You Serve? Who Do You Protect?: Police Violence and Resistance in The United States," will be released next month. Come get a sneak peek this weekend, at this discussion featuring several of the activists and journalists who contributed to the book: Alison Flowers, Kelly Hayes, Sarah Macaraeg, Page May, and Monica Trinidad. Maya Schenwar, one of the book's editors, will moderate the panel. Early copies of "Who Do You Serve? Who Do You Protect?" will be available for purchase — and contributors will be available to sign them!

The slogan used on police patrol cars across the country, To Protect and Serve, is remarkably unspecific. Who — or what — is being protected? Who is being served? What are police actually doing in the United States, and toward what ends?
 
For us, the question is not, "How do we confront the fact that police are doing things that are wrong?" But rather, "How do we confront the institution of policing as a whole — an institution whose entire grounding and current practice is wrong?"

In this discussion, we will tackle the fundamental violence of policing and how we might move beyond this institution to a world where state violence does not systematically control people's lives.

For more info and to order the book online, see: http://www.truth-out.org/whodoyouserve

This event is part of the Evanston Literary Festival.
link_name: Who Do You Serve? A Truthout Discussion on Police Violence & Resistance

status_message:
From the US Navy's plans for war games above the Pacific Northwest, to the crackdown on protesters at the Paris climate conference, and from gentrification in the Bay Area to police violence in Chicago, here's a small sample of Truthout's most original news coverage from 2015.

status_message: A new exposé from InsideClimate News reveals nearly every major US and multinational oil and gas company was likely aware of the impact of fossil fuels on climate change at the same time as Exxon - in the 1970s.

status_message: The deluge of bad news from the Middle East in 2015 has hardened erroneous Western views of the region. Recognizing more positive news can help combat negative stereotypes and increase empathy, says Jessica Winegar.

status_message: The first job of giving birth is to survive it - which is harder to do in the US than in almost all other nations in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. It's even harder if you're African American, or live in a state with a high poverty rate.

status_message: An appreciation of that fact those killed by police in 2015 were each a unique human life lost as the result of a police decision, is what's missing from the Washington Post's tally of fatal police shootings, writes Jim Naureckas.

status_message: US businesses weakened the Kyoto Protocol, leading it to require only a 7 percent reduction in emissions (compared to the 20 percent requested by European nations) and then President Bush refused to sign on to even that. The late Aaron Swartz details how they did it.

status_message: On Christmas Eve in 1914, in the midst of World War I, the two sides of the war sang carols to one another. Artillery fire stopped. status_message: A workshop training on key elements of conflict resolution and peer mediation for street children in Afghanistan was a success, says Kathy Kelly. But I couldn't help but see how Americans are in need of the same skills and knowledge of nonviolence.

status_message: Bayou Corne, 77 miles west of New Orleans, has joined the growing list of communities destroyed by industrial accidents. The town is known for its giant sinkhole and deserted population, with only 10 homes remaining occupied.

status_message: One kilo of protein from either beef or lamb reared on a British hill farm causes more greenhouse gas emissions than a passenger flying from London to New York. We miscalculate environmental risk; eating certain meats is about the worst thing you can do to the planet.

status_message: From a cancelled hydro dam that spares 20,000 people from the burden of displacement, to a simple court admission that Indigenous peoples do actually make the best conservationists, Indigenous rights victories give us all pause to celebrate, to reflect and to rejuvenate our own quests for justice.

status_message: Smuggling a Christmas tree through ISIS checkpoints; praying that the doors do not close in the faces of the refugees from your country like they were closed in the faces of Mary and Joseph on Christmas Eve. Maybe Christmas is about trying to find a miraculous way to penetrate an extremely painful memory and paint some love into it.

status_message: Economist Warren Mosler, a leading figure in the field of modern monetary theory, discusses money, debt and the role of the European Union's deficit limits in perpetuating the Greek crisis, and shares what he believes could help lead Greece out of its crisis.

status_message: I pause and wonder what it is I am promoting when I inculcate my daughter with the odd mythology of the season, writes William Rivers Pitt. Hold your favorite toy in the palm of your mind's eye. That is the US economy today, a fancy dream, well-constructed, but ultimately hollow.

status_message: Since October, residents of Porter Ranch, California, have been exposed to dangerous contaminants from a massive natural gas leak that continues to seep into the air, causing a catastrophe the scale of which has not been seen since the 2010 BP oil spill.

status_message: We can't directly console Guantánamo detainees, but together we can invite people to think about their actual circumstances and relationships with supposed "enemies." status_message: A "performance pay" loophole allowed 10 US corporations alone to cut their 2014 tax bill by more than $182 million through CEO pay-related deductions. Taxpayers who have seen their wages stagnate have been forced to subsidize the pay of those who sit atop the largest businesses.

status_message: Bill Berkowitz talks with professor and activist Susan Greenbaum about the ineffectiveness of current policies aimed at reducing poverty, and how these efforts often reinforce negative stereotypes about the economically disadvantaged.

status_message: Hillary Clinton claims that "nobody" supports sending US ground troops to Syria, but in reality, any candidate who calls for the US to establish a "safe zone" in Syria is actually calling for the deployment of ground troops, says Robert Naiman.

status_message: Titanium mining is threatening communities' ecological stability and disrupting collective decision-making practices in Chiapas.

status_message: The Federal Communications Commission is poised to make a decision this month that would overhaul an industry that has been making millions from phone calls made by incarcerated people throughout the United States.

status_message: Thousands of emails reveal how the biotech giant Monsanto enlisted public university academics to prop up their massive PR machine.

status_message: The medical community's stigmatization of women suspected of using substances during pregnancy can have devastating consequences.

status_message: After sealing off East Jerusalem neighborhoods last week, Israel is widening its crackdown on Arab residents and continuing military operations across the West Bank and Gaza.
link_name: Israel-Palestine: As Stabbings, Shootings Kill Dozens, Endless Occupation Fuels Resistance

status_message: It is critical for Canadians to vote Prime Minister Stephen Harper and his ruling Conservative Party out of office today, says Pamela D. Palmater. Harper has become a triple threat to social peace and well-being in the country.
link_name: Canada Is in a Crisis of Epic Proportions

status_message: Lael Brainard, a member of the Fed's Board of Governors, gave a speech in which she questioned the need for the Fed to raise interest rates. A rate hike became even more unlikely when another governor seconded Brainard's position, says Dean Baker.

status_message: Déborah Berman-Santana, a retired professor of geography and ethnic studies, describes her personal process of decolonization as a Puerto Rican, and speaks to Truthout about the ongoing economic crisis there.
link_name: Puerto Rico's Debt Crisis: Greece Isn't Alone in Struggling Against Austerity

status_message: Social justice activists love to hate private prisons. The loathing is easy to justify, says James Kilgore. But while private prisons receive much of the blame for mass incarceration, such firms own or control only 9 percent of prison and jail beds in the US.

status_message: Indignation about inequality is likely to grow with new data from the Credit Suisse Global Wealth Databook, which reveals the wealthy elite's continuing disdain for the poor, the middle class and for people all around the world.
link_name: New 2015 Wealth Data: US Inequality at Its Ugliest

status_message: Pregnant women who use controlled substances are being incarcerated and losing custody of their children, instead of receiving the treatment they need. Now, other women who have lived through similar experiences are offering support.
link_name: Managing Addiction While Pregnant: Women Who've Been There Call for Harm Reduction

status_message: Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper has aggressively pushed for tar sands development, championing Keystone XL and a host of other pipelines and energy projects - while downplaying or outright ignoring their potential impact on climate change.

status_message: If someone had poisoned New York's water supply and killed 9,000 people, it would have been the most litigated public health disaster of all time. But when it happened in Haiti? Nothing.
link_name: Haiti's Earthquake Was Devastating, but the Cholera Epidemic Was Worse

status_message: Super PACs are supposed to be both transparent and independent from the politicians they are supporting. But it's not clear that Right to Rise USA, the super PAC formed by Republican Jeb Bush prior to his presidential bid, is either.
link_name: Is Pro-Bush Super PAC Obscuring Spending?

status_message: Author Premilla Nadasen discusses how relatively isolated Black women domestic workers organized in the 1960s and 1970s for higher wages, better labor conditions and respect and dignity in the workplace. The domestic labor movement they built offers lessons on how marginalized workers can organize today.

status_message: This account unveils the hidden history of a worldwide detention network run by the CIA and facilitated by its foreign partners.

status_message: When media outlets cover the issue of sexual violence, they often produce oversimplified accounts that reinforce rape myths. These narratives minimize survivors' experiences of violence and expose them to more danger.

status_message: Incarceration takes an immense financial and emotional toll on relatives of prisoners, particularly on women family members. Increasingly, many women are organizing with others to challenge these high costs and fight the laws that fuel mass incarceration.

status_message: Countries in Latin America have always dealt with refugees, migrating either from neighboring countries or from abroad. In order to address this persistent issue, the region unified to create three important documents: The Cartagena Declaration on Refugees, the Mexico Plan of Action and the Brazil Declaration and Plan of Action.
link_name: Latin America Unified in Addressing Refugee Crisis

status_message: Galeano will be remembered around the world as a champion of human liberation through solidaristic action. It remains to us to fulfill the legacy he leaves, by pursuing justice with the same immediacy and intensity that he conveyed history.
link_name: The Last Gift of Eduardo Galeano: Stories of History for the Sake of the Future

status_message: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) is an organization shrouded in mystery. This may be due mainly to the fact that the majority of people don't even know of its existence.

status_message: It is hard for photojournalist Julie Dermansky to believe Rupert Murdoch's outlook won't influence National Geographic's content, even though the magazine insists it will retain editorial control.

status_message: Did we attack the Kunduz hospital on purpose, or was it just a tragic mistake? Such obsessive short-sightedness overlooks a slightly larger question: Why are we in Afghanistan in the first place? Shouldn't that be what's on trial?
link_name: Afghanistan Is Proof That if We Valued Human Life, We Wouldn't Wage War

status_message: The World Bank itself has cautioned that unabated climate change threatens to reverse hard-earned development gains - and that the poorest countries and communities will suffer the consequences first and worst. However, a sober review of its lending practices reveals the Bank is undermining the cause it purports to champion.
link_name: How the World Bank Undermines Climate Change Efforts

status_message: William Rivers Pitt: There have been some 87,000 gunfire-caused funerals since the horror of Sandy Hook. That's just here. How many millions around the world has this nation delivered into the crippling agony of loss? The reason: We have been tamed, taught not to care, numbed to the point of incapacitation. We're sad for a day, maybe, and then we forget.
link_name: Know It to the Bone

status_message: After five decades of shrewd strategy, the Republican coalition Richard Nixon put together in 1968 - welcoming the segregationist white South into the Party of Lincoln - is now devouring itself in ugly, spiteful recriminations.

status_message: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which regulates interstate energy operations in the US, calls itself an "independent" agency. But anti-fracking activists and other critics say the agency rarely denies pipeline permit requests to the energy industry that funds it via annual charges and filing fees.
link_name: The Federal Agency Behind the Gross Expansion of Fracking Pipelines

status_message: The federal government has decided not to increase benefits this year for Social Security recipients. The needs of seniors are proportioned differently than most Americans - and the bottom line is that they have experienced reduced spending power in the last year.

status_message: Abby Martin explores the history of anti-communism in the US, and the heavy repression of an idea that became an unofficial religion.

status_message: Social democracy simply means that society should leave room for small enterprises and individual liberty, but also recognize the fact that we're all part of a larger community, says Bernard Weisberger.

status_message: The national security state and the military seem to have created an un-intelligence system.

status_message: In 2012, workers at Serious Materials occupied their workplace to save their jobs. Today, employees of what is now called New Era Windows and Doors are also the owners.

status_message: An analysis of debt collection judgments from three metropolitan areas - St. Louis, Chicago and Newark - showed that even accounting for income, the rate of judgments was twice as high in mostly black neighborhoods.

status_message: Perhaps the most harmful state policy implemented in the wake of 9/11 is the National Security Entry-Exit Registration System, writes Deepa Iyer.

status_message: The widespread benefits of the digital revolution are hiding the totalitarian potential of an electronically connected world, writes Chet Bowers. status_message: On ancestral lands, the Fond du Lac band in Minnesota is planting wild rice and restoring wetlands damaged by dams, industry and logging. Their efforts are part of a growing trend by Native Americans to bring back traditional food sources and heal scarred landscapes.

status_message: The Trans-Pacific Partnership is the archetype of an agreement that exists only for the benefit of the entitled, politically powerfully lobbyists who have pushed it through to completion over the last eight years.

status_message: There are Columbus statues and place names around the United States; only George Washington has more infrastructure named after him. status_message: In July, Paul Castaway, a mentally ill Indigenous man, was shot and killed by Denver police. Castaway's mother, Lynn Eagle Feather, speaks about her son's case and the protests that have since taken place in his name.

status_message: "It seems reasonable to ask something of the companies that get tens of millions of loan subsidies through the Ex-Im Bank," writes Dean Baker.

status_message: Crawford, Nebraska, was an unlikely setting for a federal hearing, but it became the site of one in late August thanks to the dogged determination of a group of Lakota and environmental activists, as well as geologists, hydrologists and lawyers - all of whom have been fighting the permit renewal of a uranium mine located in town.
link_name: Lakota Women and Ranchers Lead Charge to Break Silence Against Uranium Mine

status_message: Ann Marie Sayers is a rare example of a Native woman who continues to live in her ancestral land. California Indians suffered a brutal history of colonization, diseases and heinous violence and servitude during the Gold Rush and California Missions era.

status_message: The USDA recently announced $35 million in grants to support local and regional food systems. Local food systems are emerging as a promising piece of community economic development and a key component of Appalachia's transition away from extractive industries.

status_message: A small fishing village on the Caribbean coast of Honduras has become an example to be followed in renewable energies, after replacing candles and dirty costly energy based on fossil fuels with hydropower from a mini-dam, while reforesting the river basin.

status_message: Republicans must decide if they belong to the party of Lincoln or a xenophobic group similar to the Know-Nothing Party of the 1800s, writes Cary Fraser. With his anti-immigrant, nationalist rhetoric, GOP presidential candidate Donald Trump is pushing the party toward the latter.

status_message: The United States has supported the indiscriminate use of fumigations to control pests, like the Mediterranean fruit fly, in Central America. The practice has been described as "low-intensity chemical warfare," as it threatens not just the targeted insects, but also humans and the environment.
link_name: When We Fumigate Flies and Mosquitoes, Are We Poisoning Ourselves?

status_message: Last month, the Seattle City Council resolved to end the practice of putting young lawbreakers behind bars. Resolution 31614, which passed unanimously, is a commitment to "eliminate the need to detain or incarcerate youth" by cutting off the "school-to-prison pipeline" and finding alternatives to incarceration.
link_name: Justice Can Be Served Without Putting Kids Behind Bars

status_message: The Iraq cables show us the myriad methods the US used to bring its new subjects of empire to heel, along with the nefarious tactics employed to conceal, obfuscate or "spin" the truth.

status_message: In just seven years, the Sovereign Citizen movement, a movement that most Americans know little about, has vaulted to the top of the list of terrorist threats to the homeland according to a survey of law enforcement officials.

status_message: Carved out of a taxpayer-subsidized wildlife refuge, Delaware's first and only national park faced development threats to much of its border before the new park signs were in the ground. The ongoing risks come largely from developers connected to a nonprofit originally founded to conserve the land.
link_name: Private Developers Cash in on Delaware's Only National Park

status_message: Bombing a hospital, especially with deliberate intent is depraved and utterly reckless. Not only did the US kill patients and staff members from all over the world, who were working there because of a commitment to give help to those in harm's way, but it destroyed one of the few medical centers in a city with a population of over 300,000.

status_message: It would be easy to dismiss Jeb's callous belittling of a mass shooting as a reassurance to the NRA, which is a key financial and voting-block supporter of presidential candidates.

status_message: An investigative report released this week documents how some for-profit college owners have converted their companies into non-profit schools in a way that allows them to evade the regulatory obligations.

status_message: In this shantytown, where more than 1,500 families are exposed to industrial pollution, the children suffer the problem in their blood.

status_message: Even though Green Party presidential candidate Jill Stein has little to no chance of winning the election, her progressive positions on foreign policy matter.

status_message: When it comes to US gun violence, guns and racism remain the driving force behind both our highly armed police forces and white vigilantes.

status_message: Republican politicians are bought and paid for by the gun industry, and that is why common-sense gun reform was voted down, and the violence continues.

status_message: As the shale rush swept across the US, underfunded state regulators have been forced to scramble to learn the mechanics of a complex industry. Now those regulators are being offered a topnotch, all expenses paid crash course, funded by the very industry they are meant to regulate.

status_message: International media coverage has reduced the war in Syria to a series of tragic images and statistics, but there is another layer to the crisis that many have overlooked, says Morgan Curtis.

status_message: Mexico's military, police forces and organized criminals have created one of the most deadly armed conflicts in the world. But despite the heavy death toll, the government interventions have not significantly reduced the amount of drugs entering the United States.

status_message: In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, we were led to believe that the tragedy was the result of a natural disaster and government incompetence, writes Henry A. Giroux. status_message: When even Greece's leading voice against austerity falls into line with the creditors, the country's in big trouble.

status_message: From retail to real estate, from employment to the criminal legal system, the use of data mining, scoring software and predictive analytics programs is proliferating at an exponential rate. Software that makes decisions based on data like a person's ZIP code can reflect, or even amplify, the results of historical or institutional discrimination.

status_message: In more than 25 states, threatened eviction is sanctioned by local laws - interchangeably called crime free ordinances, disorderly behavior ordinances and nuisance ordinances. These funds are critically needed for our budget, in order to make the reporting and analysis we publish possible.

That seems like a huge challenge but if everyone who likes our Facebook page chipped in just $2, we'd more than reach our goal - we'd smash past it! Can we count on you for help?

As a nonprofit news site that refuses to take ad money or corporate sponsorship, we reply on our readers to keep us going from month to month. Your donation is tax-deductible and we promise that any amount you can spare helps!
link_name: Situation Critical!

status_message: Chicago's Pride Parade now celebrates everything from big banks to Budweiser, and includes a police float and prison labor cleaning up its trash. status_message: Following the Supreme Court's historic decision on gay marriage, our humanity demands that any celebration of this moment be part of a march forward - one where we are willing to hold each other accountable in the pursuit of real justice and safety for those who will not benefit from this victory, writes Kelly Hayes.

status_message: For the elites, trade agreements like the TPP are a no-brainer.

status_message: Last Wednesday, Josh Fox, director of Gasland, the documentary which exposed the harms of the fracking industry, was arrested along with 20 other people after forming a human barricade at a natural gas storage facility in upstate New York.
link_name: "We Are Seneca Lake": Josh Fox and Fracking Opponents Fight Natural Gas Storage Site in Upstate...

status_message: We are entering an era of stop-go austerity, in which politicians who refuse to learn the right lessons from history doom their citizens to repeat it, says Paul Krugman.
link_name: Welcome to the Era of Stop-Go Austerity

status_message: A three-storey, rickety wooden vessel, filled with hundreds of desperate men, women and children may soon become a floating graveyard, as a handful of Southeast Asian countries continue to refuse to allow the ship to come to port.
link_name: Boatloads of Migrants Could Soon Be "Floating Graveyard" on Southeast Asian Waters

status_message: The growing corporate branding of the public commons, nonprofit events and just about anything that you can't nail down, has become both a visual blight and a disturbing sign of the times, says Mark Karlin.

status_message: The US government's 12 year battle to prevent the release of evidence of systemic torture has slowly eviscerated the FOIA process in ways that now threaten the First Amendment.

status_message: Laura Flanders talks with Black Lives Matter co-founder Patrisse Cullors about building a movement that connects policing, poverty, LGBTQ issues, and the violence and racism the United States exports through its foreign policy.

status_message: The Medicare cuts in the trade adjustment assistance bill set a dangerous precedent, allowing Congress to treat Medicare like its own personal piggy bank.

status_message: Slavery made the US wealthy, and racist policies since have blocked African American wealth-building. Can we calculate the economic damage?
link_name: Forty Acres and a Mule Would Be at Least $6.4 Trillion Today: What the US Really Owes Black America

status_message: Chris Crass interviews members of Jewish Voice for Peace, an anti-racist group that is trying to organize white community members to do their part to combat racism.
link_name: Jewish Voice for Peace Speaks on White Racial Justice Organizing in Black Lives Matter Times

status_message: Behind Apple's public image - one that portrays the company as an almost magical source of innovation - lies a culture of theft and exploitation, says Paul Buchheit.
link_name: How Apple Corporation Plunders Its Customers and the Nation

status_message: A Chicago man claims he was sexually assaulted with a metal object, believed to be a handgun barrel, by police at Chicago's now infamous Homan Square facility, which some have characterized as a domestic "black site."
link_name: As Chicago Pays Victims of Past Torture, Police Face New Allegations of Abuse at Homan Square

status_message: As the 2016 presidential candidates belatedly get worked up about inequality, they're losing touch with reality, says Donald Kaul.
link_name: Send in the Clowns

status_message: While Chevron may have positioned itself as a corporation benefitting from the "free-speech" rights provided by the 2010 Citizens United ruling, Chevron's spending in Richmond, California proved downright wasteful.

status_message: Gareth Porter questions a key element of Seymour Hersh's story about the raid that killed Osama bin Laden.
link_name: The Misfire in Hersh's Big Bin Laden Story

status_message: John Pilger discusses the life and loss of Kwementyaye Randall, an Australian Indigenous hero.

status_message: Accountability measures for the federal charter school initiative were a paradoxical afterthought, and they simply don't work, says  Jonas Persson.
link_name: Charter School "Flexibility" Linked to Major Failures; More Than $3.3 Billion in Taxes Spent

status_message: In matters of racial equality, the United States has yet to transcend the sins of its founders.
link_name: US "Original Sin" and the 2016 Presidential Election

status_message: Government, mainstream media and the military-industrial economy are converging in a lockstep, armed obsession over various enemies of the status quo in which they hold enormous power; and this obsession is devolving public consciousness into a permanent fight-or-flight mentality.
link_name: The US Government Continues to Squander its Legitimacy as it Militarizes

status_message: Wisconsin Republicans want to bar people from using their food stamps to buy shrimp, lobster, and other shellfish, and require them to use at least two-thirds of their SNAP benefits on items found on a specific and arbitrary list of products. Being poor is stressful enough without being kicked while you're down.
link_name: Wisconsin's Grocery Dictators

status_message: We know that the US Department of Defense doled out $5.4 million from 2011 to 2014 to 14 NFL teams to stage these warm-hearted "Salute the Troops" events, as well as do product placement, advertising and "casual" (otherwise known as "subliminal") mentions.
link_name: Why Are We Paying the NFL to Help the Pentagon Recruit Troops?

status_message: New understandings of accountability can ultimately transform reality, but only if we take up our own share of responsibility for acknowledging the history of torture in the US and changing what comes next.
link_name: Torture, Lies and Denial

status_message: Great damage was done to US soldiers, and those who survived still suffer the agony of that long ago war, writes Michael D. Yates. However, these pale by comparison to the brutality suffered by the Vietnamese, a violence still very much alive in the daily lives of the people in that much tried nation.
link_name: Honor the Vietnamese, Not Those Who Killed Them

status_message: Author, journalist and professor Christian Parenti speaks with Truthout about the history of right-wing, anti-statist attitudes in the United States, applying Marxism to ecology and how human society has and can be a positive force to protect the environment and biodiversity.
link_name: Christian Parenti on the State, Humanity as Part of Nature and the Malleability of Capitalism

status_message: The unprecedented wave of state-level anti-abortion restrictions introduced this year is being met by a growing number of bills that would regulate crisis pregnancy centers, storefronts masquerading as reproductive health clinics, often funded by anti-choice religious organizations.
link_name: Activists and Faith Leaders Push Back on Fake Reproductive Health Clinics

status_message: William Rivers Pitt: Why has Obama chosen the Trans-Pacific Partnership as his legacy? Is he what many of us have feared he is for a while now: a Trojan Horse president, presented at the gates as a progressive gift?
link_name: The Trojan Horse President

status_message: Women work, and increasingly they are filling jobs with few benefits, low wages and unpredictable schedules. Our workplace laws threw women of color under the bus from the beginning, but we will all get run over if we don't reinvent our system to get everyone on board, writes Caroline Fredrickson in this excerpt of her book, "Under the Bus."
link_name: How US Working Women Are Being Run Over

status_message: If anything, the Amtrak incident reveals the need for more government funds, not less - unless the US is to become derailed by a transportation sector that is build around the needs of corporations and the fossil fuel industry instead of the survival of our planet, writes Mark Karlin.
link_name: Eight Amtrak Deaths Reveal How US Transportation Policy Has Derailed

status_message: Industrial agriculture has become a prime driver of many of the world's most serious problems: the loss of wild and farmed biodiversity, huge climate-changing emissions and the entrapment of small farmers in ever-deepening cycles of poverty. But there is a solution: the widespread adoption of agroecological farming.
link_name: Can Agroecology Save Us From "Scorched-Earth" Agriculture?

status_message: Here are the basics: Hundreds of companies were caught using tax avoidance schemes in the country of Luxembourg. It was exposed by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, and now those who exposed this massive tax issue are under threat.
link_name: What Is LuxLeaks and Why Are Journalists Being Charged?

status_message: Our media cannot represent the public in any just and logical way because they sustain the imbalances already in place, probing for answers in a way that converts what is transparently clear into a muddle of indecisiveness, writes Joseph Natoli.
link_name: Endless Deferment of Meaning: The Media's Inequitable Melee of Events and Words

status_message: Seafaring activists in a fleet of kayaks are planning a direct action off the coast of Washington State this weekend to protest Shell's plan to drill in the Arctic and the Port of Seattle's decision to allow Shell oil rigs to dock at the port.
link_name: Paddle Up! Resistance to Shell's Arctic Drilling Grows on Land and Sea

status_message: In February, a press release by the US Treasury Department pushed the Israeli propaganda line about worldwide Hezbollah terrorist cells - this time in Nigeria. A closer look at the case reveals that Mossad had engineered a frame-up of two Lebanese businessmen through its power over Nigeria's State Security Service.
link_name: How the US Treasury Department Promotes Israel's Propaganda Lines

status_message: Most bees aren't the snazzy hive-dwelling orange and black characters we know so well. In fact, there are around 20,000 species of bee globally and just seven of these are honeybees. So what about the rest?
link_name: There's Much More to Bees Than Queens, Honey and Hives

status_message: The world's two best-known climate economists - William Nordhaus and Nicholas Stern - disagree radically on most issues. But they agree on one: The most effective policy for slowing global warming would be a price on carbon.
link_name: Carbon Tax or Carbon Market?

status_message: The pay-gap statistics released by the AFL-CIO this week are further confirmation that only true systemic economic change can lead us to a just income distribution in the US.
link_name: CEO-to-Worker Pay Rises to a Ratio of 373-1, AFL-CIO Finds

status_message: Brave New Films provides an animated look at why the power of the Federal Reserve needs to be reexamined.
link_name: Fed Up: Why The Federal Reserve Needs Reform

status_message: Matt Bors speculates about how Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy makes his judicial decisions: http://www.truth-out.org/art/item/30807-swing-vote-secrets
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: In the wake of today's death penalty sentence for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, we're sharing again William Rivers Pitt's argument that the state does not have the moral right to kill an unarmed, defenseless person, even when that person is someone we despise.
link_name: Mercy Is Ours to Give, if We Choose It

status_message: Antonia Juhasz discusses what she observed during a dive in the Alvin submarine nearly a mile below the ocean surface, getting closer to the site of the BP oil spill blowout than anyone had ever been.
link_name: Thirty Million Gallons Under the Sea: Five Years After BP Disaster, New Drilling OK'd by Spill Site

status_message: "Good Kill," a new film based on the real experiences of drone operators brings to life the insidious risks of waging war abroad without ever leaving home.

status_message: With six-year-olds in squad cars over dress code violations, it's clear the legal system has become a racialized go-to for even the most minor transgressions of children.

status_message: As more corporate members admit they are lobbying for favorable legislation through ALEC, progressive watchdogs are accusing the right wing policy group of tax fraud and requesting that the IRS take action.

status_message: The medicalization of white crime allows society to divert more white and middle-class children and adults from the juvenile and criminal justice systems, while continuing to criminalize people of color.

status_message: When abortion opponents attempt to erase all consideration of a pregnant woman's health and circumstances from the conversation, it's time for some real talk, says Amy Hagstrom Miller.

status_message: On questions of stimulus and austerity, the opinions of politicians, media figures and big business types should be given substantially less weight than those of mainstream economists, says Paul Krugman.

status_message: Editor and reporter Adam Federman discusses a new report that confirms for the first time that the FBI spied on activists in Texas who tried to stop the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline.

status_message: Hundreds of people marched to Wisconsin's state Capitol on Tuesday in protest of the Dane County district attorney's decision not to charge a police officer with the shooting of Tony Robinson, an unarmed Black teenager who was killed in March.
link_name: Wisconsin Activists to Continue Protests After Cop Avoids Charges in Killing of Tony Robinson

status_message: Why is a multibillion-dollar pipeline being classified as an "intrastate" one, when the project is being touted publicly as an international one? Alyce Santoro breaks down this fossil fueled case of regulatory dodge ball.

status_message: Labor advocates say that programs that encourage safer conditions for nail salon workers don't go far enough. To protect workers from exploitation and toxic fumes, the industry must be further regulated.

status_message: The United States of America must oppose torture and ban its use absolutely. That begins in the Oval Office, and Obama needs to belatedly do something about it, says John Kiriakou.

status_message: The murder of 43 Atyotzinapa normalistas in September was a bloody warning to public school teachers who interfere with the privatization of Mexico's schools.

status_message: President Obama's fears about Elizabeth Warren's impact on fast-track TPP legislation were realized on Tuesday when the Senate failed to pass a filibuster-proof vote.

status_message: Conjuring up the debt monster is how the water sector has hustled cities around the nation into selling off their water systems.

status_message: This week marks 67 years since the founding of the State of Israel, known to Palestinians as the Nakba, or "tragedy." status_message: When your tracks are crumbling, your bridges are falling apart and your trains are dinosaurs from the 1970s, it's time to throw money at the problem.

status_message: Author Caroline Fredrickson shares her findings on how female workers continue to be economically shortchanged in the United States.

status_message: The recent maritime migrant crisis neared the proportions of the Titanic's sinking, without illiciting any comparable public outcry. With destructive trade deals like the TPP on the horizon, William C. Anderson says we should be prepared for more of the same.

status_message: We should be skeptical of those in power who claim they have a solution to the Syrian conflict - a solution already attempted in Libya, with disastrous results.

status_message: Public defenders in Baltimore warn that the haphazard arrest and ill treatment of hundreds of area residents, like cop watcher Geremy Faulkner, could further fuel the community's fears that justice will not be served.

status_message: The government's prosecution of Jeffrey Sterling was a stern warning to potential whistleblowers: Do not talk to reporters.

status_message: Many of us wonder what possible reason could exist for the failure to invest in infrastructure in the US and create millions of jobs. Paul Buchheit looks at the personality traits, beliefs and misconceptions of billionaires that might account for such behavior.

status_message: On Monday, former CIA officer Jeffrey Sterling was sentenced to 42 months in prison for leaking classified information to New York Times reporter James Risen about a failed U.S. effort to undermine Iran's nuclear program.

status_message: The House of Representatives is poised to pass the USA Freedom Act of 2015, which would end bulk collection of metadata from domestic phone companies, but would leave in place a sweeping surveillance program focused on international communications.

status_message: In a state that's running dry, activist Susana de Anda is fighting to ensure that all Californians have access to clean, safe water.

status_message: The "nation of takers" narrative, which asserts that we have been contributing ever-greater sums toward helping the poor, all without making a dent in the poverty rate, needs to be debunked once and for all, says Paul Krugman.

status_message: The settlement of a suit that claimed the Department of Veterans affairs had misused resources has brought an end to a three year old case, and furthered the fight to end homelessness among Los Angeles veterans.

status_message: Vincent Emanuele talks with journalist and professor, Christian Parenti about examining wars and conflicts in the context of global environmental destruction.

status_message: It is time to flood the senate with phone calls, argue Kevin Zeese and Margaret Flowers, before the first vote on "fast track" that would allow the president to sign the Trans-Pacific Partnership  and other harmful rigged corporate agreements into law before Congress or the people see them.

status_message: House Bill 40 might become law as early as today, making Denton's fracking ban unenforceable. status_message: Like Israel, Saudi Arabia has embraced a military strategy that yields high civilian casualties and few military gains.

status_message: President Obama may feign outrage over the lack of support for the TPP, but no one should be surprised that progressives don't want to go along for this ride, says Dean Baker.

status_message: Recent reports and audits reveal that many states have no idea how charter schools actually spend federal money, and have no systematic way of obtaining or verifying information about their expenditures.

status_message: Monetary bail often results in jail time for poor and mentally ill individuals before they have ever been convicted of a crime.

status_message: Bernie Sanders' populist agenda provides a new platform for immigration rights activists to demonstrate that undocumented immigrants and other marginalized communities are fighting the same rigged system.

status_message: Adam Finberg's new film makes a bold claim: Many purveyors of addiction treatment are selling false hope.

status_message: More than 100 women small farmers from Chile's southern Patagonia region have joined together in a new association aimed at achieving economic autonomy and empowerment, in an area where machismo and gender inequality are the norm.

status_message: Every semester, Jean Trounstine takes her students to prison, where they experience confinement to some degree and listen for an hour to an incarcerated man talk about his life and what it is like to be behind bars.

status_message: Invoking the "Bad Men" clause of the 1868 Fort Laramie Treaty means roughly 40 percent of South Dakota is off limits to TransCanada. This would directly affect the proposed Keystone XL pipeline route and the access to transmission lines.

status_message: Whether defending the rights of their imprisoned children or their own rights, these mothers of resistance are fighting for a better, more equitable tomorrow for the next generation.

status_message: Following reports that scientists at the US Department of Agriculture are being harassed and their research on bee-killing pesticides is being censored or suppressed, a broad coalition of farmers, environmentalists, fisheries and food-safety organizations urged an investigation.
link_name: Is the Government Harassing and Censoring Scientists for Studying Ties Between Pesticides and...

status_message: "Motherhood is work," writes William Rivers Pitt. "But it is noble work, blessed work, and the dividends paid when the job is done right do not just reward the mother."
link_name: They Call It "Labor" for a Reason

status_message: In this interview with Brad Evans and Henry A. Giroux, the public intellectuals discuss their forthcoming book, what they mean by "disposable futures" and "dystopian realism," and how the spectacle of violence has contributed to a mistaken societal view that there is no future except a brutal one under neoliberal capitalism.
link_name: Challenging a "Disposable Future," Looking to a Politics of Possibility

status_message: After her arrest last year, Shanesha Taylor was subjected to brutal demonization in the media and the courts. Taylor, a single mother of three, recalls how her dire economic situation and struggle to find gainful employment led to her criminalization for being "poor while Black."
link_name: Poverty, Jail, Media Harassment: The Worst Year of This Mother's Life

status_message: Michael Blake died last week. You probably don't know the name. You probably don't know about his life. Michael Blake fused history and social issues, writing about social justice. Writing books that mattered. Writing screenplays that were never produced and then discarded.
link_name: A Life That Mattered

status_message: By throwing in with the for-profits, traditional schools might be able to capitalize on Republican control of Congress.
link_name: Higher Education Lobby Quietly Joins For-Profit Schools to Roll Back Tighter Rules

status_message: This book is about the bait-and-switch that has historically constrained American workers' freedom under liberal capitalist democracy: enticed with the American Dream, they are simultaneously denied a collective route to fulfill its promise.
link_name: Free to Be a Free Rider

status_message: Landless rural workers occupy farms in Brazil to fulfill the promises of a people's agrarian reform movement. During "Red April," the Landless Workers Movement (MST) remembers the Eldorado dos Carajas massacre and pays tribute to 21 fallen comrades who were killed by state police.

status_message: The aura of historic San Francisco, that heartland of American bohemia now almost thoroughly yuppified yet stubbornly gorgeous, offers a universal appeal. The Tenderloin, for its part, is more of an acquired taste.
link_name: San Francisco: The High Life of the Lowlifes

status_message: Author and professor Antonia Darder recalls her 30-year journey in academia as a working-class woman of color and how her deep sense of justice has inspired her scholarship and allowed her to survive and thrive in an institution that forced her to do battle with colonizing patriarchy, racism and class privilege.

status_message: After the World Health Organization declared glyphosate a probable carcinogen, the campaign has intensified in Latin America to ban the herbicide, which is employed on a massive scale on transgenic crops.

status_message: Syriza has failed dismally in its quest to change Europe's political economy through negotiation, and it now appears that Greece will remain in the grip of austerity and debt peonage for a long time to come, says C.J. Polychroniou.

status_message: While megabanks make megabucks, local banks are financing businesses that create jobs.

status_message: Last fall, the city of Denton passed Texas' first outright ban on fracking, but Texas Republicans have now passed a bill invalidating that historic victory.

status_message: A century ago, Congress enacted the estate tax to stem the concentration of wealth and close the gap between haves and have-nots. This time around, it's doing the exact opposite.

status_message: While Cuba does stand to benefit from the restoration of economic relations with the United States, this is largely attributable to the developmental policies of the Cuban state during the embargo.

status_message: We have a right to film the police. So why do people keep getting arrested - or worse - for doing it?

status_message: Rampant privatization is wreaking havoc on our society. Case in point: what's happened over the past few decades with prison phone services.

status_message: Get the truth out? We couldn't possibly agree more...

status_message: The World Bank's proposal for water privatization in Lagos, Nigeria, has foundered, apparently dismissed as unworkable and unprofitable. Could this point toward a global trend of making water services public once more?

status_message: Supreme Court Justices Samuel Alito and Antonin Scalia recently argued that marriage equality opens the door to polygamy, underage sex and incest. This is the modern equivalent of McCarthy red-baiting, argues Bill Quigley, and it deserves the same response.

status_message: There remains a major disconnect between the perception that the US has of itself and how the country is perceived abroad.

status_message: In the third of a four-part series, Truthout reveals patterns of institutionalized police bias in Chicago's handling of police shootings deemed "justified," and finds the vast majority of misconduct complaints are effectively purged.

status_message: Severe Tropical Cyclone Pam, which swept through the South Pacific Island state of Vanuatu in mid-March, has deepened hardships faced by people living in the informal settlements of the capital, Port Vila. status_message: The Thai government estimates that up to 300,000 people work in its fishing industry, 90 percent of whom are migrants - and therefore vulnerable to being duped, trafficked and exploited.

status_message: "The aim of the project is to show that because of the conflict, the most vulnerable parts of the population suffer. And people are suffering on both sides. status_message: All the Senate does is make it a lot harder for the citizens of big states like New York and California to have a say in our political system. Whether it's through amending the Constitution or breaking up the states, a change needs to happen.
link_name: The Republicans Didn't Really Win the Senate

status_message:
An internet quiz for the NYPD: http://www.truth-out.org/art/item/28346-quiz-time-back-turning-nypd-edition

By Jen Sorensen
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: Nobel laureate Joseph Stiglitz talks about his recent book, "The Price of Inequality," and the need for the field of economics to come to terms with the growing gulf between haves and have-nots.
link_name: Joseph Stiglitz: Economics Has to Come to Terms With Wealth and Income Inequality

status_message: The release of the Senate's report on US torture has been accompanied by a dangerous false narrative, according to which torture is a past crime and exclusive to the Republican Party, says Julio Sharp-Wasserman.
link_name: How Outraged Is the Obama Administration About Torture?

status_message: New York City may become the first municipality in the country to provide free legal representation to low-income tenants facing eviction.
link_name: NYC Activists Mobilize for Right to Counsel in Eviction

status_message: Young people from immigrant families who are forced to work out of financial necessity are among those pinning their hopes on the Fight for 15 movement.
link_name: When the Teenager Is the Breadwinner

status_message: Most of the attention paid to corporate tax avoidance is directed at federal taxes. But state taxes, which to a much greater extent fund K-12 education, are avoided at a stunning rate by America's biggest companies.
link_name: Cheating the School Kids: Corporations Don't Pay Their State Taxes, Either

status_message: The environmental, social and geopolitical implications of the Interoceanic Grand Canal of Nicaragua could cast a shadow over the region for decades to come.
link_name: Panama Canal Rival: Work Starts in Nicaragua Amid Fears Over Environment and Role of China

status_message: It is time to take social change seriously by imagining a future beyond the austerity policies and power relations that define the misery and violence of a neoliberal social order, writes Henry A. Giroux.
link_name: Authoritarianism, Class Warfare and the Advance of Neoliberal Austerity Policies

status_message: The seven million dollar price tag attached to Jim Harbaugh's first year at the University of Michigan may seem a bit steep, but like a lot of high salaries at non profits, it's subsidized with your tax dollars.
link_name: Does the University of Michigan's New Football Coach Need Food Stamps?

status_message: Maryland's outgoing governor has announced a reprieve for each of the state's four inmates who were still lingering on death row, two years after the state took capital punishment off the table in all future court cases.
link_name: Maryland Governor Ends Death Penalty Immediately

status_message: Erich Fromm was a sociologist, a psychoanalyst, the author of more than a dozen books, a social commentator and a political activist who promoted worldwide socialist humanism and nuclear disarmament. Lawrence J. Friedman's book, "The Lives of Erich Fromm," is a virtual encyclopedia of Fromm data.
link_name: A Godless Jewish Humanist

status_message: The rapid expansion of the United States' right-wing media began in the 1980s as the Reagan administration coordinated foreign policy initiatives with conservative media executives, including Rupert Murdoch, and then cleared away regulatory hurdles.
link_name: Murdoch, Scaife and CIA Propaganda

status_message: "We all know, or at least should realize, that our good intentions do not exempt us from the failings of our society," writes Kelly Hayes. "Despite all we have learned, we still stigmatize what we should not, and at times, put social expediency before the creation and maintenance of safer spaces."
link_name: Addiction, Mental Health, Safe Spaces and Stigmatization

status_message: In this interview, Robert McChesney, author of "Blowing the Roof Off the Twenty-First Century," discusses net neutrality advocacy, how the concentration of capital and media monopolies stifle democracy, and his hopes for a post-capitalist democracy in the United States.
link_name: Robert McChesney: We Need to Advocate Radical Solutions to Systemic Problems

status_message: Port truckers in California walked off the job in November to protest their dismal working conditions. Required to lease trucks while paying insurance and maintenance costs, drivers often earn less than minimum wage.
link_name: Port Strikes Mirror Organized Labor's Roots

status_message: Those permanently shut out of their former lives since the Fukushima Daiichi power plant spiraled into meltdown include some who have been in as many as 10 shelters in three-and-a-half years.
link_name: The Fourth Winter of Fukushima

status_message: Focusing on the problems already identified with the McMindfulness craze obscures a more profound issue - meditation neglects meaning. This not only opens the door to grave dangers, but also compromises meditation's radical emancipatory potential, writes Dr. Jeffrey B. Rubin.
link_name: The McMindfulness Craze: The Shadow Side of the Mindfulness Revolution

status_message: Washington has doubled down on maintaining a steady supply of weapons and funding to governments willing to support US strategic interests, regardless of how they treat their citizens.
link_name: Doubling Down on Dictatorship in the Middle East

status_message: "Nature used to let us know when was the best time for each step, in farming. But now, Pachamama is confused, and we are losing our reference points among the animals and the plants, which don't have a flowering season anymore," a Quechua community leader says.
link_name: Climate Change Threatens Quechua and Their Crops in Peru's Andes

status_message: Now that the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act has expired, the horrors inflicted by the United States on human beings abroad have more potential to cut into the bottom lines of insurance brokers and developers.
link_name: Terrorism "Insurance" Expires

status_message: There are those around the world who regard the United States as the world's biggest self-touting "democracy" that regularly violates human rights.
link_name: Cuba Has a Strong Case That the US is a Violator of Human Rights

status_message: If change comes to American schools, it will come, as the end of slavery did, as the result of a thousand and one acts of resistance and rebellion, says Jay Gillen in his new book, "Educating for Insurgency: The Roles of Young People in Schools of Poverty."
link_name: Flipping the Script: Pedagogy, Theater and Radical Organizing in Schools of Poverty

status_message: In his book, Matt Taibbi asks why the vast majority of white-collar criminals have avoided prison since the financial crisis began, while an unequal justice system imprisons the poor and people of color on a mass scale.
link_name: Who Goes to Jail? Matt Taibbi on "The Divide: American Injustice in the Age of the Wealth Gap"

status_message: If talk show host Dr. Oz were the kind of guy who pored over medical evidence to be sure he knew what he was talking about, he probably couldn't project the persona that wins him such a large audience. A similar situation may be true for some economists, says Paul Krugman.
link_name: Economists as Entertainers

status_message: The emergence of the Kurdistan Workers' Party - branded a terrorist organization by the EU, the US and NATO - as a deterrent to the Sunni jihadists and the Islamic State has led to somewhat uncomfortable reactions in Turkey and the West.
link_name: Rise of IS Brings Turkey's Rabid Rejection of Kurdish Rights to Fore

status_message: Sadly, still too many liberals claim to oppose Israeli settlement expansion in the West Bank, but object far more strenuously to anyone actually trying to do anything concrete to stop it, says Robert Naiman.
link_name: Let's Not Punish the Palestinians for Joining the International Court

status_message: Rick Williams asked for calm when protesters demanded justice for his brother, who was shot and killed by a Seattle police officer.
link_name: How This Indigenous Wood Carver Is Finding Peace After a Seattle Officer Killed His Brother

status_message: The loss of Officers Rafael Ramos and Wenjian Liu, like the deaths of Eric Garner and Michael Brown, has left families broken by pain. But quickly their murders were transformed into a political spectacle used to delegitimize the Black Lives Matters movement, says Nicholas Powers.
link_name: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: Black Lives Matter Movement Hits Counterreaction

status_message: Will Uncle Sam become Cuba's best friend again? Experts say no one should bank on an immediate boom in US-Cuban business transactions. They've got a good point, says Emily Schwartz Greco.
link_name: Washington's Slow-Motion Thaw

status_message: Torture is illegal and immoral, known to be ineffective in extracting "intelligence" and an inferior way of creating desired "intelligence." Why then has the state condoned its use?
link_name: Reflections on Torture: The Real Reason Why

status_message: The war isn't really ending. Some 18,000 foreign troops will stay in Afghanistan under a new mission called "Resolute Support." Incredibly, we're not letting go. We're just disappearing the combat mission into global background noise.
link_name: Afghan People Suffer Because of US Investment in Nation-Wrecking

status_message: President Vladimir Putin managed to get himself into a confrontation with the West over Ukraine just as the bottom dropped out of his country's main export, says Paul Krugman.
link_name: Vladimir Putin's Unraveling Russia

status_message: If Cuba were to take a deep breath and look at what's happened to an island it has shared such a deep history with, and if Cuba were to see Puerto Rico as the beginning of the free-trade economic era we're living in now, it would have to ask itself, is it the end game?
link_name: A View on Cuba's Opening From the De Facto US Colony of Puerto Rico

status_message: In 2014, we saw a lot of brutality. It was a violent year, but no worse than other years. What was different was the emergence of new movements of resistance - and with them new possibilities for change.
link_name: Ten Ways Human Rights and Democracy Won in 2014

status_message: If there were such a thing as a "Hall Of Fame Of Suck," the year 2014 would not only win first-ballot admission, it would have its very own wing. Consider this an abridged butcher's bill, says William Rivers Pitt.
link_name: Planting a Seed for 2015

status_message: Today, California is part of a profit-driven global system that must plunder and pollute the planet to survive. Major sectors of the economy like agribusiness, tourism and construction depend on cheap labor drawn from outside the state, says Craig Collins.
link_name: California: Waking Up Is Hard to Do

status_message: The furious denunciations of the president's initiative on Cuba from his adversaries reveal only an intellectual void on Capitol Hill, where the imperatives remain partisan and cynical, says Joe Conason.
link_name: Joe Conason: Ending a Cuba Policy That's Failed for 50 Years

status_message: Finding alternative frameworks that reinvigorate "democracy for all" will be the biggest challenge facing Western democracies in the coming decades, says Thomas J. Scott.
link_name: Democracy and Its Discontents
